# Crate persyCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/settings.html)

Expand description
## [§](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/#persy---transactional-persistence-engine)Persy - Transactional Persistence Engine
Simple single file durable, isolated, consistent, and atomic persistence engine based on copy on write. It guarantee the persistence of data even in case of crash through a in file write ahead log, and provide simple rust APIs for store simple bytes or value associated (index) data, provide also memory management logic to keep the file size in check.
## [§](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/#example)Example
```
use persy::{Persy,Config};
//...
Persy::create("./target/data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_segment("seg")?;
let data = vec![1;20];
tx.insert("seg", &data)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (_id,content) in persy.scan("seg")? {
  assert_eq!(content[0], 1);
  //....
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/#example-index)Example Index
```
use persy::{Persy,Config, ValueMode};
//...
Persy::create("./target/index_data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/index_data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_index::<i32,i32>("index", ValueMode::Cluster)?;
tx.put("index", 10, 20)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (key,values) in persy.range::<i32,i32,_>("index", ..)? {
  assert_eq!(key, 10);
  assert_eq!(values.into_iter().collect::<Vec<_>>(), vec![20]);
  //....
}
```

    Wrapper for `Vec<u8>` for use it in index keys or values

    Persy configuration structure.

[IndexId](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.IndexId.html "struct persy::IndexId")
    Unique identifier of an index

[IndexInfo](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.IndexInfo.html "struct persy::IndexInfo")
    Index definition details

[IndexIter](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.IndexIter.html "struct persy::IndexIter")
    Index Iterator implementation for iterating on a range of keys

[OpenOptions](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.OpenOptions.html "struct persy::OpenOptions")
    Options, flags, configs which can be used to configure how a persy database is opened.

[Persy](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.Persy.html "struct persy::Persy")
    Main structure to operate persy storage files

    Identifier of a persistent record, can be used for read, update or delete the record

    Intermediate recover status to select witch transactions to commit or rollback and list witch transactions are in a intermediate state

    Represents a looked-up segment

    Iterator implementation used to scan a segment

[Snapshot](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.Snapshot.html "struct persy::Snapshot")
    Read snapshot at a specific point in time.

[SnapshotSegmentIter](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.SnapshotSegmentIter.html "struct persy::SnapshotSegmentIter")
    Iterator implementation to scan a segment at the current snapshot state.

[Transaction](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.Transaction.html "struct persy::Transaction")
    Transaction container, it include all the changes done in a transaction.

[TransactionConfig](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.TransactionConfig.html "struct persy::TransactionConfig")
    Configure the parameters for the transaction on the begin of a new transaction.

[TransactionFinalize](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.TransactionFinalize.html "struct persy::TransactionFinalize")
    prepared transaction state

[TxIndexIter](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.TxIndexIter.html "struct persy::TxIndexIter")
    Index Iterator implementation for iterating on a range of keys considering changes in transaction

[TxSegmentIter](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.TxSegmentIter.html "struct persy::TxSegmentIter")
    Iterator implementation to scan a segment considering in transaction changes.

[ValueIter](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/struct.ValueIter.html "struct persy::ValueIter")
    Iterator of values relative to an index key use by get and range functions

# Persy
[![build status](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://gitlab.com/persy/persy/badges/master/pipeline.svg)](https://gitlab.com/persy/persy/commits/master) [![coverage report](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://codecov.io/gl/persy/persy/branch/master/graph/badge.svg?token=4Hqx7T9z1w)](https://codecov.io/gl/persy/persy)
[Persy](https://persy.rs) is a transactional storage engine written in rust.
## Install
Add it as dependency of your project:
```
```[``dependencies``]`
`persy``=```"`1.6`"``
``
```

## Example
Create a new persy file save some data in it and scan it.
```
``use` `persy`::````{`Persy`,`Config```}```;`
``//`...`
`Persy`::``create`(```"`./open.persy`"```)``?``;`
`let` persy `=` `Persy`::``open`(```"`./open.persy`"```,``Config`::``new`(``)``)``?``;`
`let` `mut` tx `=` persy`.``begin``(``)``?``;`
tx`.``create_segment``(```"`seg`"```)``?``;`
`let` data `=` `vec!``[``1``;``20``]``;`
tx`.``insert``(```"`seg`"```,` `&`data`)``?``;`
`let` prepared `=` tx`.``prepare``(``)``?``;`
prepared`.``commit``(``)``?``;`
`for` `(`_id`,` content`)` `in` persy`.``scan``(```"`seg`"```)``?` ``{`
  `assert_eq!``(`content`[``0``]``,` `1``)``;`
  ``//`....`
```}``
`
```

## Docs
Check the [get started](https://persy.rs/posts/getting-started.html) and the [APIs](https://docs.rs/persy/) look for all the version on [crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/persy)
## Compile The Source
Checkout the source code:
```
```git``` clone https://gitlab.com/persy/persy.git`
`
```

Compile and Test
```
```cargo``` test`
`
```

## Contacts
Follow Persy on [Mastodon](https://fosstodon.org/@persy_rs) for news and announcements, join the [#persy_rs:matrix.org](https://matrix.to/#/!uTwEQyCLprxxbYLvjG:matrix.org?via=matrix.org) for have a chat.
## Contributing
You can find the code on our [Repository](https://gitlab.com/persy/persy) and report any issue in our [Issues Tracker](https://gitlab.com/persy/persy/-/issues)
If you want to have an active part on the Persy development, you can start from reviewing and suggesting API changes, jump directly to hacking the code or just playing a bit with docs. If you want a list of possibility you can start from the list of [Good First Issue](https://gitlab.com/persy/persy/-/issues?label_name%5B%5D=Good+First+Issue)

# Crate persyCopy item path

Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/src/persy/lib.rs.html#1-676)
Expand description
## [§](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/#persy---transactional-persistence-engine)Persy - Transactional Persistence Engine
Simple single file durable, isolated, consistent, and atomic persistence engine based on copy on write. It guarantee the persistence of data even in case of crash through a in file write ahead log, and provide simple rust APIs for store simple bytes or value associated (index) data, provide also memory management logic to keep the file size in check.
## [§](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/#example)Example
```
use persy::{Persy,Config};
//...
Persy::create("./target/data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_segment("seg")?;
let data = vec![1;20];
tx.insert("seg", &data)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (_id,content) in persy.scan("seg")? {
  assert_eq!(content[0], 1);
  //....
}
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/persy/latest/persy/#example-index)Example Index
```
use persy::{Persy,Config, ValueMode};
//...
Persy::create("./target/index_data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/index_data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_index::<i32,i32>("index", ValueMode::Cluster)?;
tx.put("index", 10, 20)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (key,values) in persy.range::<i32,i32,_>("index", ..)? {
  assert_eq!(key, 10);
  assert_eq!(values.into_iter().collect::<Vec<_>>(), vec![20]);
  //....
}
```

## §⟨4⟩Persy - Transactional Persistence Engine
Simple single file durable, isolated, consistent, and atomic persistence engine based on copy on write. It guarantee the persistence of data even in case of crash through a in file write ahead log, and provide simple rust APIs for store simple bytes or value associated (index) data, provide also memory management logic to keep the file size in check.
## §⟨5⟩Example
```
use persy::{Persy,Config};
//...
Persy::create("./target/data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_segment("seg")?;
let data = vec![1;20];
tx.insert("seg", &data)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (_id,content) in persy.scan("seg")? {
  assert_eq!(content[0], 1);
  //....
}
```

## §⟨6⟩Example Index
```
use persy::{Persy,Config, ValueMode};
//...
Persy::create("./target/index_data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/index_data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_index::<i32,i32>("index", ValueMode::Cluster)?;
tx.put("index", 10, 20)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (key,values) in persy.range::<i32,i32,_>("index", ..)? {
  assert_eq!(key, 10);
  assert_eq!(values.into_iter().collect::<Vec<_>>(), vec![20]);
  //....
}
```

## §⟨4⟩Persy - Transactional Persistence Engine
Simple single file durable, isolated, consistent, and atomic persistence engine based on copy on write. It guarantee the persistence of data even in case of crash through a in file write ahead log, and provide simple rust APIs for store simple bytes or value associated (index) data, provide also memory management logic to keep the file size in check.
## §⟨5⟩Example
```
use persy::{Persy,Config};
//...
Persy::create("./target/data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_segment("seg")?;
let data = vec![1;20];
tx.insert("seg", &data)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (_id,content) in persy.scan("seg")? {
  assert_eq!(content[0], 1);
  //....
}
```

## §⟨6⟩Example Index
```
use persy::{Persy,Config, ValueMode};
//...
Persy::create("./target/index_data.persy")?;
let persy = Persy::open("./target/index_data.persy",Config::new())?;
let mut tx = persy.begin()?;
tx.create_index::<i32,i32>("index", ValueMode::Cluster)?;
tx.put("index", 10, 20)?;
let prepared = tx.prepare()?;
prepared.commit()?;
for (key,values) in persy.range::<i32,i32,_>("index", ..)? {
  assert_eq!(key, 10);
  assert_eq!(values.into_iter().collect::<Vec<_>>(), vec![20]);
  //....
}
```

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `persy` crate is a transactional persistence engine that provides a simple, durable, and atomic single-file storage solution based on copy-on-write and an in-file write-ahead log. It supports storing raw bytes, indexed key-value data, and includes features like crash recovery, memory management for file size optimization, and snapshot-based read isolation. The crate offers a robust API for managing segments, indexes, and transactions with strong consistency guarantees.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Transactional Persistence  
✅ Factual: The `persy` crate provides transactional persistence with ACID guarantees, ensuring data consistency even in the event of a crash through its write-ahead log mechanism.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `persy` crate does not support transactional operations, and all changes to the database are applied immediately without isolation or atomicity.  

---

### Pair 2: Indexing Support  
✅ Factual: The `persy` crate allows users to create indexed data structures using the `ValueMode` configuration, enabling efficient range queries and key-value lookups.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `persy` crate does not support indexing, requiring users to manually implement search and retrieval mechanisms for stored data.  

---

### Pair 3: File Size Management  
✅ Factual: The `persy` crate includes memory management logic to keep the database file size optimized by reclaiming unused space during operations.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `persy` crate does not manage file size automatically, and database files grow indefinitely without any cleanup or optimization mechanisms.
